title: Joline Blais
text:
Joline Blais is a writer, educator, <a href="new%20media">new media</a> scholar, and <a href="permaculture">permaculture</a> designer.
As Associate Professor in the <a href="University%20of%20Maine">University of Maine</a>'s <a href="http%3A//newmedia.umaine.edu">New Media Department</a>, Blais teaches classes on digital narrative, <a href="sustainable%20design">sustainable design</a>, and permaculture. With <a href="Jon%20Ippolito">Jon Ippolito</a> in 2002, she co-founded <a href="Still%20Water">Still Water</a>, a new media <a href="Laboratory">lab</a> she continues to co-direct that is devoted to studying and building creative <a href="Social%20network">networks</a>. Blais' publications and creative work explore the overlap of <a href="digital%20culture">digital culture</a>, <a href="indigenous%20peoples">indigenous culture</a>, and <a href="permaculture">permaculture</a> which has included advocacy for updated tenure and promotion criteria based on sharing rather than hierarchical principles.
Selected Projects.
Blais' 2006 book <a href="https%3A//www.amazon.com/dp/0500238227">At the Edge of Art</a>, co-authored with Ippolito and published by <a href="Thames%20%26amp%3B%20Hudson">Thames & Hudson</a>, investigates how new media art puts the power of networks and distributed creativity into the hands of ordinary citizens in a variety of non-art contexts. The book creates a metaphor between <a href="digital%20art">digital art</a> and the human <a href="immune%20system">immune system</a>, relating the auto-immune response to the important role of art in society. In this book Blais coins the terms "autobotography," personal histories automatically recorded by digital devices such as <a href="webcam">webcam</a>s and blogs, and "executability," an ability of 21st-century expression to operate on computable, social, or legal codes.
Blais and collaborators, including <a href="John%20P.%20Bell">John Bell</a>, Ippolito, and Owen Smith, developed <a href="http%3A//pool.newmedia.umaine.edu">The Pool</a>, an online project design workspace noted by the <a href="Chronicle%20of%20Higher%20Education">Chronicle of Higher Education</a> as a "new avenue for new-media scholars to do their jobs." The Pool is a collaborative online environment for creating art, <a href="code">code</a>, and <a href="Text%20file">texts</a>. In place of the single-artist, single-artwork paradigm favored by the overwhelming majority of documentation systems, The Pool stimulates <a href="collaboration">collaboration</a> in a variety of forms, including multi-author, asynchronous, and cross-medium projects.
In 2005 Blais partnered with New York's <a href="Eyebeam%20Art%20and%20Technology%20Center">Eyebeam Art and Technology Center</a> to conceive and produce an online forum on open culture that spanned six weeks and four continents. Entitled <a href="Distributed%20creativity">Distributed creativity</a>, this system wove together correspondents from separate email lists based in California (<a href="Creative%20Commons">Creative Commons</a>), New York (<a href="Rhizome%20%28organization%29">Rhizome</a>), Ireland (DATA), India (<a href="The%20Sarai%20Programme%20at%20CSDS">Sarai</a>), and Australia (Fibreculture) in a global conversation on the future of creativity, intellectual property, and mobile media.
Her sustainability projects include <a href="http%3A//longgreenhouse.org">LongGreenHouse</a> (2007–2011), which wove the <a href="Wabanaki%20Confederacy">Wabanaki</a> Longhouse, permaculture gardens, and networked collaboration in a hybrid "communiversity," in partnership with UMaine, the Wassookeag school, and Wabanaki elders. Other projects include RFC: Request for Ceremony, a call for re-investing quotidian life with ceremony; and the Cross-Cultural Partnership, a legal framework for developing trust networks with indigenous peoples.
In 2008 Blais expanded this work from the university to community contexts as a partner and equity member of <a href="http%3A//MaineCohousing.org">Belfast Cohousing & Ecovillage</a>, whose <a href="Carbon%20neutrality">net zero</a> prototype house was the US Green Building Council's <a href="http%3A//www.usgbc.org/Docs/News/LEED%2520for%2520Homes%2520Awards%25202011.pdf">2011 Project of the Year</a>.
